Review: Max Payne 3 is a cover based third person shooter. It has extremely satisfing shooting along with very nice visuals and soundtrack. The shooting in MP 3 is some of the best out there. Your crosshair is a single dot which means you have to be very precise with every bullet you shoot. The sounds the weapons make and the gore make all the weapons extremely pleasant to shoot. The games story is pretty good as well. I wont get too into because spoilers but as someone who did not play MP 1 or 2 it did a good job telling me what is happening. The only downside is a big one, you cannot skip the cutscenes, thus making replayability a lot less fun than it should be. Review: Rise of the Tomb Raider is alright. I personally don't think its anything special but it works and does everything it wants to do. Tbh I completely skipped the story, I watched the first cutscene and didnt watch any of the others lol (I wont count story in the final score) Visuals are great. Goes for a gritty realistic style and nails it. Looks beautiful even 6 years later. Gameplay is fun. Its a pretty standard third person shooter. You take cover and pop out every once in a while to kill enemies. The platforming is actually really fun. I wasnt expecting to enjoy it as much as I did. You are jumping from cliff edge to cliff edge, climbing rocks, grappling hooking on stuff, its all a lot of fun. The real fun comes from mixing combat with platforming. You'll be shooting an enemy on one side while grapple hooking over and shotgunning another enemy on the other side. Its a ton of fun. Review: Index with Knuckles I thought I would like this game and did for about 75% of the way through.   Then the whole experience derailed into an annoying tedious janky rest of the way.   The more I played this the more I feel this is analogous to a point and click adventure set in a VR package.   I like point and click adventures but they can also get old .   I found myself just wanting this to be done with.    The controls are pretty janky which isn't unique to VR games that I have experienced.   Trying to pick up this when you wanted to pick up that.....but the developers didn't design the things and devices with VR in mind.   Things were too close together a lot of times for puzzles or had awkward hand placement and unresponsive movement.   On top of this, some of the puzzles were timed based.   This all added to a frustrating experiences that overwhelmed any potential fun I was having.    The puzzles were sometimes obtuse and the fact that manipulating puzzles was hard, it just made it more irritating than enjoyable.   This was an inventory nightmare and I'm glad I read that you should keep everything in one place; otherwise you will forget where you put things and have a hard time finding it.     The story itself was blah, as it didn't go into the plot very much except once or twice during the 10 hour experience other than the last part - and the ending was meh.  Not worth the trouble at this point.   I feel like I went 75% and just felt since I've gone this far might as well see it through.  Not glad I did.  Never get that time back.   I loved the concept of what they did though and I think they might iron things out in the remaster, hopefully.
